captions.text:
MATT FARAH: Today on Tuned,
I'm driving that.
[ENGINE REVVING]

MATT FARAH: This
should be fun.

It's been 12 years since The
Fast and the Furious turned a

generation of young tuners into
fans of the big powered
Toyota Supra.

In those 12 years most of the
Supras have been modified into

oblivion, while the kids who
loved them have grown up to

work for tech startups or hedge
funds, but they still
lust after big horsepower.

Only now, the cars don't
just come from Japan--
some of them come from Italy.

In an unassuming warehouse
surrounded by a pond, trees,

and industrial buildings not
worth a second glance, you'll

find the workshop of the first
person to add two turbos to a
Lamborghini.

His name is Jason Heffner, and
his shop doesn't need a sign,

because his cars speak
for themselves.
[ENGINE REVVING]

JASON HEFFNER: This
car operates at
seven pounds of boost.

It makes roughly 800 horsepower
at the wheels,

which equates to close to 950
horsepower at the flywheel.

I want to say in about 2003, we
moved from superchargers to

turbo systems, and quickly
realized that it was obviously
the way to go.

MATT FARAH: Now that you've
experienced the sights and

sounds of the Heffner twin turbo
Gallardo, let me show

you what it's like right
here to do a pull.
[ENGINE REVVING]

MATT FARAH: The twin turbo
Gallardo is like today's
modern tuned Supra.

In the late '90s and the early
2000s, the big turbo Supra was
the big thing.

You could make 800, 900, 1000
horsepower out those cars, but

they haven't made
them in a while.
They're tough to find.

The Gallardo is great because,
A, it's a Lamborghini, B, it

depreciates like it's not a
Lamborghini, so you can pick
up a used one.

This is a 560, but you can
get a used Gallardo

And then for $40,000 at Heffner,
you can add 800 to

the wheels and get
it stuff like--
[ENGINE REVVING]

MATT FARAH: I remember another
video that I said there was

nothing better than a V8 with
turbo blowoff noise.

A V10 with turbo blowoff
noise might be better.
[ENGINE REVVING]

JASON HEFFNER: It sounds good,
it feels good, but the German

engineering keeps the
car together.

It makes it a more reliable
platform.
These cars hold up very well.

You have to be mindful
of the big picture.

You can't let one aspect of the
car exceed the capacity of
the rest of the car.

If we're going to upgrade the
engine to a certain point, or

beyond a certain point, we have
to upgrade the rest of

the car to be able to
withstand where
we're taking it.

But generally speaking, the
cars are very reliable.
[ENGINE REVVING]

MATT FARAH: Now, the reason I
like Heffner is because he was
the first person to do this.

He was the first person to put
twin turbos on a Ford GT, the

first person to put twin
turbos on a Gallardo.

Hell, even in the '90s, this
guy supercharged a Diablo--
who supercharges a Diablo?

And he built his name on the
fact that that Diablo, which

is a notoriously fragile
car, didn't explode.

If you're going put a $40,000
turbo kit on a $200,000

exotic, you want that
reliability.

You want to know that you'll
be able to drive that thing
without it blowing up.

And so Heffner does what he has
to do in order to keep the
car reliable.

He drops the compression a
little bit, he beefs up the

halfshafts and the clutch,
if necessary.

It works, in case you're
wondering--
it works quite well, actually.

Now I remember last year I
drove a Gallardo by BF

Engineering, supercharged
engine.

And at the time I said that a
supercharger was better than

twin turbos on Lamborghinis,
because it makes the power

everywhere, not just the
top of power band.
That's partially true.

While the VF kit does make more
torque at the low end,

there is something wonderful
about the feeling of turbo

boost building and that
sound that you hear.

You know, with a supercharged
car, you didn't really
hear a whole lot.

It just sounded like
a stock car.
It just went faster.

But if you're going to spend
$40,000, isn't that sound
something you kinda want?
I mean, it's a--
[ENGINE REVVING]

JASON HEFFNER: Although we're
primarily known for our work

on the Lamborghinis and the Ford
GTs, we work on a pretty
wide variety of cars.

Basically, anything that
somebody comes to us that

sounds interesting or
challenging, we're willing to
take it in and give it a shot.

Over here, we've got a super
performance Shelby Cobra.

This car is getting a 427-inch
small block Ford.

It'll have full Motech
electronics, Garrett GT30Rs,

and at 2,100 pounds will make
somewhere in the neighborhood

of 1,000 horsepower
when it's done.

Next to that, we have
an Ultima GTR.

That car right now weighs in
at about 2,200 pounds.

It has a twin turbo 5.4 liter
Ford GT engine, as well with

Garrett GT30Rs, built aluminum
intake manifold, Motech

electronics, and will have the
capability of making close to
1,200 horsepower.

MALE SPEAKER: Is there any
such thing as too much
horsepower?
JASON HEFFNER: Yes.

I feel that you cross the line
between the right amount of

power and too much power when
you can no longer go in your

garage, fire the car up, take it
out and drive it around for

a day without having to
worry about failure.

You need to be able to put the
power to the ground, you need

to be able to drive the car when
you want to drive it, and

with all of our builds that
we put out for street

applications, we remain
very mindful of this.

We want to send somebody a well
balanced car that's going

to work every time they need it,
and if someone wants to go

further and build a race car,
we offer that as well.
[ENGINE REVVING]

MATT FARAH: Woo,
that's a rush.
[LAUGHING]

It's like shooting yourself up
with turbo boost right there.

This is like the Nikki
Sixx of turbo boost.

He's doing lines of ants, and
then he's just injecting boost
into his veins.

I think we're covered
there, yeah?
MALE SPEAKER: Yeah.
Cut.

MATT FARAH: Well, we've
got some road.

Let's see what the first
gear's like.
I'm just going to--

ESP off, [INAUDIBLE],
traction off.

Let's just mat it and
see what happens.
[ENGINE REVVING]

MATT FARAH: I'm not going to
tell you how fast that was.
I'm just not.

JF would be very, very angry
at me if I did, but you are

going to have to trust
me that it was quick.

title: The 900 HP Heffner Twin Turbo Lamborghini LP-560 -- /TUNED

UGR lambo is a stage 2R Gallardo and has nowhere near the capabilities of 
the Heffner. The 2R lambo has broken 6 times and I expect more in the 
future unfortunately. If anyone asks, it may be much less powerful, but the 
Heffner is waaaaay better in every aspect.﻿

comments.author: Vagelis Gameplays

comments.text:
I sold my stage 2R UGR Gallardo 4 months after I bought it. The tranny was 
the first to go, then a few hoses broke, and many minor problems followed 
that led me to sell it. I never bashed them until after and convinced 3 
friends to buy this instead. They haven't had 1 problem and they've driven 
these cars for over a year, constantly pushing their limits, often multiple 
times a day.
comments.author: alex symmes

comments.text: +Logan Burris :/
comments.author: Vagelis Gameplays

comments.text:
+Vagelis Gameplays I live in Charlotte. Home of UGR. I've seen their cars 
do work and I have a friend with a 2000hp gallardo. He has more trouble 
with it than any other car of his and he has some BIG power cars. He will 
be the first to say he wishes he had trailered his car to Florida and had 
it built at Heffner.
comments.author: Logan Burris

comments.text:

have done bad jobs on plenty of cars. They aren't any better than Hennessy.

comments.text:
Absolutely awesomely amazing! I'm a DIEHARD Lamborghini fan so the Heffner 
Gallardo is right up my alley. I have pretty extensive experience with 
turbochargers having owned and hand built many variations of the Mitsubishi 
4G63t and 4G61t engines. I only have one question, (and I'm sure that I'm 
not the only one that's thought of it), when will Heffner release the 
Murcielago and/or Aventador twin turbo models? Definitely can't wait! I 
wish that I still lived in Brandon.﻿

5 years.

comments.author: MrBasarcan

comments.text:
+[AKA] Kraut! Not even close. That's like saying a Veyron is just two Audi 
4.0 V8's bolted together on an A8 turned into a coupe. I visited the 
factory in Italy. They may be the "same" motor, but all units that are used 
in Lamborghinis are hand built there in  Sant'Agata Bolognese. There are a 
few parts taken from the Audi bin here and there like the AWD, 
transmissions and such, but it is so much more than just a nicer Audi.
comments.author: Edwin Peck

go to high school and college, you are fully capable of owning such a car
